Certainly, here are some ways you can turn the cons of starting a flower supply business into advantages:

1. Highly competitive: Instead of trying to compete with established players, you can differentiate yourself by offering unique flower arrangements, personalized services, or focusing on a niche market. For example, you could specialize in providing eco-friendly or locally grown flowers, which would appeal to customers who prioritize sustainability.
2. Seasonal business: While the demand for flowers may be seasonal, you can use this to your advantage by diversifying your offerings to include seasonal products, such as Christmas wreaths or Valentine's Day bouquets. You could also offer flower subscriptions, where customers receive regular deliveries of fresh flowers throughout the year, providing a steady income stream.
3. Perishable goods: To ensure the quality of your flowers, you can emphasize the importance of timely delivery and invest in refrigeration equipment to keep the flowers fresh. You could also educate your customers on how to care for their flowers properly, increasing their satisfaction and repeat business.
4. Short shelf life: You can use the short shelf life of flowers to your advantage by offering a sense of urgency in your marketing. For example, you could create limited-time offers, such as "Today's Special," or "Limited edition bouquet," which would motivate customers to make a purchase quickly. You could also emphasize the beauty of fresh flowers and the importance of enjoying them while they are at their best.

By turning the cons of starting a flower supply business into advantages, you can create a unique selling proposition that sets you apart from the competition, attracts new customers, and keeps them coming back for more.
